EyeContact.question: You are talking to a friend at school.
options: A: I look at my friend and listen carefully.
B: I look at them most of the time but glance away sometimes.
C: I listen but often look at my phone or around the room.
D: I avoid looking at my friend because I feel shy.
E: I look away a lot and find it hard to make eye contact.

EyeContact.question: You are presenting in class.
options: A: I make eye contact with my classmates while speaking.
B: I look at my notes and occasionally look up.
C: I mostly look down at my paper.
D: I don’t look at anyone and feel nervous.
E: I only look at my friend for support.

EyeContact.question: You’re having a conversation with a teacher.
options: A: I look at the teacher and nod to show I’m listening.
B: I glance at the teacher but sometimes look at my desk.
C: I look around the room while they talk.
D: I feel uncomfortable and avoid eye contact.
E: I don’t really look at them at all.

EyeContact.question: You meet a new student.
options: A: I smile and make eye contact to welcome them.
B: I look at them but feel a bit shy.
C: I listen but often look away to avoid awkwardness.
D: I avoid looking at them and just nod.
E: I look down and don’t make eye contact.

EyeContact.question: You’re listening to a story from a friend.
options: A: I keep looking at my friend and show I’m interested.
B: I look at them most of the time but sometimes look away.
C: I get distracted and look around a lot.
D: I look at the floor while they talk.
E: I don’t really look at them and feel out of place.

Behaviour.question: You see someone drop their books in the hallway.
options: A: I help them pick up their books.
B: I watch but don’t do anything.
C: I laugh and walk past them.
D: I pretend I didn’t see anything.
E: I feel bad but just keep walking.

Behaviour.question: Your friend is upset about a bad grade.
options: A: I comfort them and help them study for next time.
B: I listen but don’t say much.
C: I tell them not to worry about it.
D: I change the subject to something else.
E: I don’t talk to them at all.

Behaviour.question: You’re in a group project and someone is quiet.
options: A: I ask them for their ideas and include them.
B: I talk to the others and forget about them.
C: I ignore them and continue working.
D: I feel annoyed that they aren’t helping.
E: I let someone else talk to them.

Behaviour.question: A classmate needs help with homework.
options: A: I offer to help them understand it better.
B: I say I can’t help but feel bad.
C: I tell them to ask someone else.
D: I just ignore them.
E: I laugh and say it’s too easy for me.

Behaviour.question: You’re playing a game and someone loses.
options: A: I encourage them to try again and cheer them up.
B: I tell them better luck next time.
C: I make a joke about it.
D: I ignore their feelings and celebrate my win.
E: I just walk away from the game.

SocialRelationship.question: You want to make a new friend at school.
options: A: I smile and say hi to them.
B: I wait for them to talk to me.
C: I just keep to myself.
D: I feel nervous and avoid them.
E: I pretend I don’t see them.

SocialRelationship.question: You see your friends chatting at lunch.
options: A: I join in and share stories.
B: I listen but don’t say much.
C: I just watch and don’t participate.
D: I feel left out and sit alone.
E: I leave the lunch area.

SocialRelationship.question: You invite a friend to hang out.
options: A: I suggest fun activities for us to do.
B: I wait for them to pick something.
C: I don’t invite anyone.
D: I feel nervous about asking.
E: I just text them without planning anything.

SocialRelationship.question: A friend is feeling down.
options: A: I ask them what’s wrong and offer support.
B: I listen but feel unsure how to help.
C: I change the subject to something light.
D: I leave them alone.
E: I ignore their feelings.

SocialRelationship.question: You see two friends arguing.
options: A: I try to help them talk it out.
B: I watch and stay quiet.
C: I take sides and argue back.
D: I walk away from the situation.
E: I laugh and find it funny.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re explaining something to a group.
options: A: I speak clearly and use examples.
B: I talk but mumble sometimes.
C: I struggle to explain what I mean.
D: I rush through my words.
E: I just keep quiet and let others talk.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re sharing a story with friends.
options: A: I tell it enthusiastically and engage them.
B: I tell it but don’t add much detail.
C: I feel shy and speak quietly.
D: I get confused and lose my train of thought.
E: I give up halfway through.

SpeechConveyance.question: You need to ask a teacher a question.
options: A: I ask confidently and clearly.
B: I mumble and feel nervous.
C: I wait until someone else asks first.
D: I ask but feel embarrassed.
E: I don’t ask anything at all.

SpeechConveyance.question: You are in a debate at school.
options: A: I present my points clearly and confidently.
B: I share my opinion but fumble my words.
C: I forget my main points during the debate.
D: I feel too nervous to speak.
E: I stay quiet and let others debate.

SpeechConveyance.question: You need to give a presentation.
options: A: I practice and speak clearly to my audience.
B: I speak but feel a bit nervous.
C: I get stuck and don’t know what to say.
D: I rush through it without much thought.
E: I avoid giving the presentation altogether.

ConcentrationLevel.question: You’re studying for a test.
options: A: I focus well and avoid distractions.
B: I study but check my phone a lot.
C: I find it hard to concentrate and daydream.
D: I get distracted easily by noise.
E: I don’t study and just hope for the best.

ConcentrationLevel.question: You’re watching a movie.
options: A: I pay full attention and enjoy it.
B: I watch but occasionally check my messages.
C: I get bored and start thinking about other things.
D: I keep talking and miss important parts.
E: I don’t watch and do something else.

ConcentrationLevel.question: You’re doing homework.
options: A: I stay focused and finish my work quickly.
B: I work but keep getting distracted by friends.
C: I often stop and lose track of what I’m doing.
D: I struggle to concentrate and take long breaks.
E: I don’t do my homework and forget about it.

ConcentrationLevel.question: You’re listening to a teacher in class.
options: A: I pay attention and take good notes.
B: I listen but occasionally zone out.
C: I find it hard to focus and get distracted.
D: I often talk to friends instead of listening.
E: I ignore the lesson and think about other things.

ConcentrationLevel.question: You’re playing a video game.
options: A: I concentrate and try to win the game.
B: I play but sometimes get distracted by chats.
C: I lose focus and miss important moves.
D: I get frustrated and stop playing.
E: I just watch others play instead.

SelfRegulation.question: You feel angry about a disagreement.
options: A: I take a deep breath and talk it out calmly.
B: I express my feelings but try not to yell.
C: I get upset and say things I don’t mean.
D: I walk away but stay angry inside.
E: I ignore my feelings and don’t talk to anyone.

SelfRegulation.question: You want to eat healthier snacks.
options: A: I choose fruits or vegetables instead of junk food.
B: I try to limit junk food but sometimes give in.
C: I eat whatever I want without thinking.
D: I forget about healthy snacks and only eat sweets.
E: I don’t care about healthy eating.

SelfRegulation.question: You’re feeling overwhelmed with schoolwork.
options: A: I make a plan and tackle one thing at a time.
B: I start but feel lost and don’t know where to begin.
C: I procrastinate and avoid my work.
D: I get stressed and feel like giving up.
E: I ignore my workload and do something else.

SelfRegulation.question: You want to improve your grades.
options: A: I set goals and study regularly to achieve them.
B: I try to study but don’t stick to my plan.
C: I don’t take my studies seriously and hope for luck.
D: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know how to start.
E: I don’t care about my grades.

SelfRegulation.question: You have a deadline for a project.
options: A: I start early and stay on track to finish.
B: I work on it but leave things for the last minute.
C: I get distracted and don’t make much progress.
D: I panic as the deadline approaches.
E: I forget about it until it’s too late.

StressLevel.question: You have a big test coming up.
options: A: I study and manage my time well.
B: I feel a little stressed but try to prepare.
C: I worry a lot and can’t focus on studying.
D: I feel overwhelmed and don’t study at all.
E: I ignore the test and do other things.

StressLevel.question: You’re in a busy class with lots of noise.
options: A: I find a way to concentrate despite the noise.
B: I feel distracted but try to focus.
C: I get annoyed and can’t pay attention.
D: I leave the classroom to get some quiet.
E: I just give up on trying to listen.

StressLevel.question: You’re handling a group project with tight deadlines.
options: A: I stay organized and communicate with my team.
B: I manage but feel some pressure.
C: I struggle to keep up and feel stressed.
D: I argue with my group because of stress.
E: I withdraw and let others handle it.

StressLevel.question: You have too many extracurricular activities.
options: A: I balance my time and enjoy my activities.
B: I feel a little overwhelmed but keep going.
C: I get stressed and sometimes miss things.
D: I feel exhausted and want to quit.
E: I don’t participate in anything anymore.

StressLevel.question: You have family or friend issues.
options: A: I talk to someone about how I feel.
B: I keep my feelings to myself but feel stressed.
C: I get upset and react negatively.
D: I avoid talking about it.
E: I ignore it and pretend it’s not there.

BodyMind.question: You’re playing a sport like basketball.
options: A: I move quickly and keep my eyes on the ball.
B: I try to keep up, but I stumble sometimes.
C: I often get confused about where to go.
D: I struggle to follow the game and feel out of place.
E: I prefer to watch rather than play.

BodyMind.question: You’re learning a dance routine.
options: A: I practice and can follow the steps easily.
B: I get some moves right but mess up a few.
C: I find it hard to remember the steps.
D: I feel clumsy and don’t enjoy it.
E: I don’t want to participate at all.

BodyMind.question: You’re drawing or painting.
options: A: I focus and create what I imagine.
B: I try, but my lines aren’t very steady.
C: I get frustrated and give up easily.
D: I feel I can’t express what I want to create.
E: I don’t draw because I think I’m not good at it.

BodyMind.question: You’re playing a video game that requires quick reactions.
options: A: I react fast and enjoy the challenge.
B: I do okay but miss some important moves.
C: I often take too long to respond.
D: I feel overwhelmed and can’t keep up.
E: I watch others play instead of participating.

BodyMind.question: You’re practicing a new instrument.
options: A: I can play the notes and enjoy it.
B: I struggle but keep trying.
C: I find it difficult and often get frustrated.
D: I feel like I’m not improving at all.
E: I don’t want to practice.

Empathy.question: A friend is feeling sad.
options: A: I listen and try to understand their feelings.
B: I tell them it will be okay but don’t listen much.
C: I change the subject to something happier.
D: I don’t acknowledge their sadness.
E: I laugh and make jokes.

Empathy.question: You see a classmate being bullied.
options: A: I stand up for them and help them feel better.
B: I watch and feel bad but don’t intervene.
C: I laugh along and don’t say anything.
D: I ignore the situation and walk away.
E: I feel uncomfortable and just stay quiet.

Empathy.question: Your sibling has a bad day at school.
options: A: I ask them what happened and listen.
B: I try to cheer them up but don’t ask details.
C: I tell them to get over it.
D: I ignore them because I’m busy.
E: I laugh and say it’s not a big deal.

Empathy.question: You see someone upset in public.
options: A: I check if they’re okay and ask if they need help.
B: I feel bad but keep walking.
C: I ignore them and look away.
D: I think they just need to toughen up.
E: I don’t care about what they’re going through.

Empathy.question: A friend shares a personal story.
options: A: I listen closely and show I care.
B: I listen but think about other things.
C: I cut them off and share my own story.
D: I act disinterested and change the topic.
E: I don’t pay attention and just nod.

Motivation.question: You set a goal to get fit.
options: A: I create a workout plan and stick to it.
B: I try to exercise but miss some days.
C: I don’t really keep track of my progress.
D: I feel like it’s too hard and want to quit.
E: I don’t care about getting fit.

Motivation.question: You want to learn a new language.
options: A: I practice a little every day.
B: I study sometimes but often forget.
C: I think about it but never start.
D: I find it too challenging and give up.
E: I don’t believe I can learn it.

Motivation.question: You want to improve your grades.
options: A: I set study goals and ask for help when needed.
B: I study occasionally but don’t stick to a plan.
C: I do my homework but don’t study much.
D: I feel stressed and don’t know where to begin.
E: I don’t care much about school.

Motivation.question: You’re working on a personal project.
options: A: I plan it out and work on it regularly.
B: I start with excitement but lose interest quickly.
C: I think about it but never take action.
D: I get overwhelmed and stop trying.
E: I don’t feel motivated to do anything.

Motivation.question: You want to help out in your community.
options: A: I find a way to volunteer and participate actively.
B: I want to help but feel too busy.
C: I think about it but don’t sign up.
D: I don’t follow through with my intentions.
E: I don’t see the point in volunteering.

SelfAwareness.question: You realize you’re feeling stressed.
options: A: I take a moment to understand why I feel this way.
B: I know I’m stressed but don’t think about it.
C: I ignore my feelings and keep going.
D: I feel confused about my emotions.
E: I just brush it off and don’t reflect.

SelfAwareness.question: You notice you’re upset about something.
options: A: I think about what made me feel this way.
B: I know I’m upset but don’t explore it further.
C: I distract myself instead of facing it.
D: I struggle to understand my feelings.
E: I don’t acknowledge my emotions.

SelfAwareness.question: You reflect on how you did in a competition.
options: A: I analyze my performance and think about improvements.
B: I feel okay about it but don’t dwell on it.
C: I forget about it and move on quickly.
D: I feel disappointed but don’t understand why.
E: I don’t care about my results.

SelfAwareness.question: You recognize your strengths and weaknesses.
options: A: I can list what I’m good at and what I need to work on.
B: I know I have strengths but struggle to see weaknesses.
C: I feel unsure about what I’m good at.
D: I focus on my weaknesses and ignore my strengths.
E: I don’t think about it at all.

SelfAwareness.question: You feel nervous before a presentation.
options: A: I acknowledge my nerves and prepare myself.
B: I know I’m nervous but try to ignore it.
C: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know what to do.
D: I pretend I’m not nervous but feel anxious inside.
E: I just avoid presenting altogether.

Mindfulness.question: You’re feeling overwhelmed by your thoughts.
options: A: I take a moment to breathe and focus on the present.
B: I try to clear my mind but find it hard.
C: I let my thoughts distract me.
D: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know how to calm down.
E: I ignore my feelings and keep going.

Mindfulness.question: You’re having lunch with friends.
options: A: I focus on my meal and enjoy our conversation.
B: I eat while scrolling on my phone.
C: I don’t pay attention to what I’m eating.
D: I feel distracted by everything around me.
E: I just eat without thinking about it.

Mindfulness.question: You’re taking a walk outside.
options: A: I notice the sights and sounds around me.
B: I walk but think about other things.
C: I’m lost in thought and don’t notice anything.
D: I feel bored and want to be somewhere else.
E: I rush through without appreciating it.

Mindfulness.question: You’re doing homework.
options: A: I concentrate fully and focus on my tasks.
B: I get distracted by my phone or TV.
C: I rush through my work without thinking.
D: I feel overwhelmed and can’t focus.
E: I often daydream while working.

Mindfulness.question: You’re having a tough day.
options: A: I take a moment to reflect on my feelings.
B: I push my feelings aside and keep going.
C: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know what to do.
D: I ignore how I feel and don’t think about it.
E: I just want to escape my thoughts.

Creativity.question: You have to come up with an idea for a school project.
options: A: I brainstorm and think of unique ideas.
B: I use some ideas I’ve seen before.
C: I struggle to come up with anything.
D: I feel pressured and can’t think of anything at all.
E: I don’t enjoy the project.

Creativity.question: You’re drawing or crafting something.
options: A: I enjoy experimenting with different styles.
B: I follow instructions but add a little twist.
C: I copy what I see instead of creating.
D: I don’t feel inspired and can’t create anything.
E: I don’t think I’m good at drawing.

Creativity.question: You’re trying to solve a problem.
options: A: I think outside the box and try different solutions.
B: I follow typical solutions but feel stuck.
C: I give up if the first idea doesn’t work.
D: I feel frustrated and don’t want to try anymore.
E: I don’t care about solving it.

Creativity.question: You’re writing a story.
options: A: I create a plot and develop interesting characters.
B: I write but use common ideas.
C: I struggle to write anything original.
D: I don’t enjoy writing and find it hard.
E: I think writing is boring.

Creativity.question: You want to design a game.
options: A: I come up with unique rules and ideas.
B: I modify an existing game a little.
C: I have trouble thinking of how to start.
D: I feel overwhelmed and don’t even try.
E: I think it’s too hard to design a game.

TimeManagement.question: You have a homework deadline coming up.
options: A: I create a schedule to finish on time.
B: I plan to start but often procrastinate.
C: I leave it to the last minute.
D: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know where to begin.
E: I forget about the deadline.

TimeManagement.question: You want to balance school and hobbies.
options: A: I set aside time for both and stick to it.
B: I try to fit everything in but get stressed.
C: I often choose fun over responsibilities.
D: I feel I have too much to do.
E: I don’t manage my time at all.

TimeManagement.question: You’re planning for a weekend event.
options: A: I make a plan and prepare in advance.
B: I think about it but don’t write anything down.
C: I rush to get things done at the last moment.
D: I feel stressed and disorganized.
E: I don’t care to plan.

TimeManagement.question: You’re preparing for exams.
options: A: I create a study plan and follow it.
B: I study a bit but don’t stick to a schedule.
C: I start studying too late and feel unprepared.
D: I feel overwhelmed and don’t study at all.
E: I don’t take exams seriously.

TimeManagement.question: You want to make time for friends.
options: A: I schedule hangouts and make it a priority.
B: I want to see them but often forget.
C: I feel too busy to spend time with friends.
D: I don’t reach out because I’m busy with other things.
E: I think friendship isn’t important.

Optimism.question: You face a challenge at school.
options: A: I believe I can overcome it with effort.
B: I hope it works out but feel uncertain.
C: I worry I won’t succeed.
D: I feel like giving up before I try.
E: I think it’s not worth the effort.

Optimism.question: You’re trying out for a team.
options: A: I feel excited and believe I can make it.
B: I hope for the best but have doubts.
C: I think I probably won’t get selected.
D: I expect to fail and feel nervous.
E: I don’t think I have a chance.

Optimism.question: You have a tough day.
options: A: I remind myself tomorrow will be better.
B: I hope things improve but feel unsure.
C: I feel overwhelmed and don’t see a way out.
D: I think every day is going to be hard.
E: I just want to stay in bed.

Optimism.question: You see someone struggling.
options: A: I believe they can improve with support.
B: I hope they find help.
C: I think it’s tough for them and feel sorry.
D: I worry they won’t get better.
E: I don’t think it’s my problem.

Optimism.question: You have a goal you want to achieve.
options: A: I’m confident I can reach it with hard work.
B: I hope to achieve it but feel nervous.
C: I doubt I can make it happen.
D: I feel discouraged and want to give up.
E: I think it’s impossible.
